comments.commentBody:
Why do Republicans want to kill anybody with a pre-existing condition? Why are Democrats the only senators who believe in the sanctity of human life?

Also, why isn't the Democratic party trotting out all of those who have benefited from this great legislative act to show how anti-American and anti-humanity its once-reputable opposition has become? Lincoln is spinning in the sod.

I will give the latest ER case. From my last shift in the ER, the patient was 61 years old male, small business owner, was having a drink with friends in a bar, felt weak, and came to the ER. Has brain bleed. Needs neurologist, Neurosurgeon, Intensive care unit, he will have very long road to recovery. This patient does not have health insurance. Now who supposed to pay for the care of this patient?. Shouldn’t this patient be “mandated” to have to buy health insurance?. Should we have left this patient to die in ambulance bay because he did not have insurance?. If it is unconstitutional to “mandate” people to buy insurance, shouldn’t it be acceptable for hospital and doctors, and staff to refuse to take care of those who refuse to buy health insurance?
Who should foot the bill for the care of this patient?

Like the mandated auto insurance protects all drivers on the road, so health insurance will protect all people -- the costs of the uninsured going to the ER are not imaginary -- those lucky/rich enough for insurance feel them in their premiums, and everyone feels them in their taxes.  Time to wake up, Republicans.  Or better yet -- do repeal the health law.  I can't wait for you to run on the platform in 2012 that you took insurance away from kids and the already sick.  That should work out real well for you.

Once Again, if the Congressional Republicans want to not be viewed with Contempt, they must first vote to eliminate their own congresionally guaranteed government health insurance first.

Until then they can shut up.

don't be surprised, friends, at the blind, massive, and never relenting hypocrisy on the part of these conservative gentlemen..who kick and scream at the possibility that people (corporations) may no longer make AS BIG and UNRESTRAINED a profit from our diseases and fears... their ideology is in large part defined by Ayn RAND, the "intellectual" who came up with such concepts as "greed is good", "the individual", and who, to sum it up, wrote that altruism is morally reprehensible-the savage free market is all that there is for us. I'm sure you know the type: child of a wealthy family who gets a raw deal when the country turns communist/socialist and finds itself at the bottom.. once she made a reputation for herself in the U.S. through right-wing pseudo-philosophy and bogus science fiction inspired intellectual activity (think Willie Buckley), she would go on to influence everyone from Greenspan to our dear P. Ryan, who not knowing any better, continues to feed off those now ancient anti-communist delusions; the most recent now being against expanding access to healthcare. RAND went on to suffer from lung cancer and the treatment was too expensive even for her writer's income. I am sure she did some rigorous soul-searching before deciding to use U.S. NATIONAL HEALTH SERVICE-MEDICARE/MEDICAI in order to cover the costs of surgery. Even the other side provides examples as to why we need this reform.
LONG LIVE HEALTH CARE REFORM IN THE UNITED STATES.

"Question: wasn't the North more industrialized, more populous and better served with railroads in 1860? Wasn't it better able to hold the country together? Didn't the 1850 Compromise really cause the secessionists to miss their best chance? Soemtimes it's beter to let things cook for a while."

Wow. What an ugly comment? What was so great about delaying the abolition of slavery? Perhaps people who were enslaved just wanted freedom. Whites had been debating it for decades, even before the crafting of the Constitution. The end of slavery in the United States was almost a hundred years too late, and the country paid dearly for it.

The people who cared more about their money and keeping government off their backs almost broke the Republic in their fight against freedom. This group never left. With every issue, especially those of fundamental human rights, these people always find a way to argue for money over people and keeping government off their backs-- no matter what the cost to the nation as a whole. Sad that we have to somehow "let things cook" until civil war breaks out for these vicious nut jobs to finally get it.

If the Repubs were serious they would have substituted Obamacare with a better plan of their own....only they don't have one and knew that their attempt at repeal would be a total waste of time and taxpayer money.....All the while lying that a majority want it repealed when the reverse is the truth.  Why won't the media confront a Senator when he lies so blatantly?

As members of the most powerful and free nation in the world, healthcare for all is must. I am not quite sure whether "Obamacare" is the correct way to go, but denying sick patients insurance in immoral and un-American. Democrats and the GOP should toil towards a sort of universal insurance that accommodates most working Americans. I believe we have to give this healthcare plan a shot.

WHEN DID THE REPUBLICANS OFFER AN ALTERNATIVE THE POTUS PLAN? WHEN? Never...

There is simply nothing underneath the hood of the 'publican party. It's not that they are without ideas, they simply haven't brought ANYTHING forward. Which I guess means that there are are no ideas from their party. So, when it comes down to debate, a party that does nothing more than feed on their own yowling will ultimately starve itself to death through their hollowness and inability to forward a single, salient thought.

I'd like to know what the Republicans want poor people to do, and people with pre-existing conditions to do when they suffer health problems and cannot find insurance or afford to pay the higher costs of direct pay?  Die??  Is visiting emergency rooms effective health care?  Is it less expensive for both the individual and for society?

Any truth to the NEW rumor that T-Mobile will have the iPhone within a year? For me, CDMA is more of a deal-killer than Verizon; I want a phone that can handle internet AND voice, and will work in the America AND the rest of the world. Also, while I like AT&T better as a company than Verizon, I *really* miss T-Mobile.I was with them for 10 years before getting an iPhone, and I loved their service.

What Mubarak is doing--holding on to power by sending police, mercenaries, hired help, Pinkertons to beat the protesters down--has been played out in almost every country on this planet at one time or another. And, yes, it's about money, profits, corporate interests, the Suez, Israel...Worries that democracy might endanger the economic status quo, that a powerful country might fall into hands that aren't all that receptive to the way things have been set up.

We have a govt who goes into Iraq and Afghanistan saying it's bringing democracy to oppressed people and that it's worth going to war and bombing the country. So why aren't people thrilled to death to see the Egyptian people demanding democracy in a peaceful but insistent manner? Why aren't the coalition of the willing cheering them on? Isn't this what they've been fighting for in the mideast for 10 years now? Democracy? Regime change?

We lack a bold vision. The president in his state of the union called for more innovation. I'd llike to see more innovation in governance. We have to stop hedging our bets and rise to the challenge of global leadership by offering a point of view. Trying to co-exist by not upsetting the apple cart is not innovative leadership. Trying to attain stability by paying off govts is not very innovative either.
Let's use some honest language these aren't "Mubarak supporters" they are government thugs who have been sent out to kill peaceful innocent people.

I have to comment on the misuse of the word 'supporter' as applied to Mubarak's thugs - and 'antigovernment' protesters as applied to Egypt's people. These term cloud the nature of the conflict. Is that the establishment sticking up for each other or just influencing the debate?

Nicolas Kristof, while risking his life in Kairo, talks of "thugs".
Others, who are sitting high and dry, are tepidly talking of "supporters".
What a difference.

Mubarek supporters? How about "Mubarek's goon squads". I heard on NPR today that these "supporters" had just been released from Egypt's prisons. And if not for the bravery of the Egyptian people, my gov't (US) would still be supporting this dictator. What a bunch of hypocrites we are.

These are not "pro-mubarak" protesters.  These are paid thugs and plain clothes security services.  Who gave them the camels and horses?  Do you think some guy in Heliopolis has a camel sitting parked in the driveway?  Did they take a taxi out to the Pyramids to rent a horse?  The government ORGANIZED it! Ben Wedeman of CNN - who has lived in Cairo for 15years and speaks Arabic like a native - said yesterday "What we have here is nothing short of a government sponsored attack on the protesters."  When "pro-mubarak" demonstrators popped Anderson Cooper 10 times in the face...what was that.  French journalists were attacked by "pro-mubarak" demonstrators, as were Arab journalists, British journalists and American journalists.  These so-called demonstrators refused to respond to questions about who they were and ones who were caught had police ID in their pocket.  OBAMA I voted for you! This is one the most pitiful, repugnant, shameful responses by an American administration I have ever seen.  Almost as bad as Rwanda....but we never gave Rwandans 1.5 billion in military aid.  WITHDRAW THE MONEY.

I've been watching Al Jazeera thru the Egyptian night and am appalled at the willingness of Mubarak to inflict such harm, and even death upon his own people. The people in the Square are brave, tired, in pain, scared, and now believe that if they give up they will be hunted down by the Mubarak supporters. For our government not to strongly press to have this stopped immediately is anathema to our own beliefs. If nothing else, the army should be stopping the pro-Mubarak thugs, by any means necessary. The common opinion on the ground in Tahrir Square is that the supporters are known police who have a vested interest in Mubarak staying in power because if he leaves, they would be under threat of crimes against humanity for their actions in Mubarak's regime. Stop support for him immediately. If Israel is an issue, just tell them to stop brutalizing Palestinians.

Egypt and Mubarak are the second largest recipient of USA military and other aid. About 1.55 billion a year. Did I say that Mubarak is part of the military? He is in our payroll. If he is not stepping down, is because his boss doesn't fire him.  Let's look at what we have done in other cases, when the people finally get tired of the tyrants we put in power, support, and assist. Then we can conclude what our guys in Washington will try to do. What they would like the most is business as usual; and if in the end that option does not work maybe a change of face.

Within the next 12 hours, I hope, President Obama will announce that the US is immediately: 1) stopping all aid to Egypt, 2)asking the International Court to try Hosni Mubarak for his crimes against humanity, and 3)freezing all Egyptian assets. A part of the yearly $1.3 billion military aid to Egypt must be -- as soon as possible -- diverted to Jordon and Yemen as economic aid.

Mr. Obama should also let his 'friend', the Saudi King, know that without the Saudi encouragement and support, Mubarak could not do what he is doing.

Thanks to 24 hour news coverage and modern technology we have all witnessed the events unravelling in the streets of Cairo, Alexandria and many other cities across Egypt. People are literally giving up their blood and soul to stand up to a ruthless dictator, who has ruled for nearly three decades. These are just ordinary people protesting rising costs, unemployment, corruption among many other things.

But wait.... rising costs? unemployment? corruption?.... these are the same issues facing the Western world. But why aren’t we protesting. We go with our huge armies and introduce “democracy” in Iraq and Afghanistan, yet we ourselves are not practicing democracy.

“We” , as in the Western world, have lost that “protester” mentality that was inside us. Whenever food prices go up we just sit there, whine about it and then accept the fact. Whenever, we drive up to the gas pump, we grumble about how these corporations are just milking our wallets, yet we still pump gas all the time. Actions speak louder than words. Joining a group on facebook or pressing the “like” button really doesn’t cut it. It is just a lazy way of saying, “Yes, we know you are stealing our money and we are going to do nothing about it.” My dad used to tell me that when he studied in India, they raised school tuitions fees, which was the equivalent of just $2. Yet they all got together, blocked streets, cornered government officials and had their voices heard.

It’s time we really stand up and fight for what we believe in, shoulder to shoulder just like the Egyptians, Tunisians, Jordanians and many other people from all over the world.

This is a great, readable, well-organized review.

The only two points I can think of are 1) did Dave really have the phones side-by-side and if so, was there a chance for crosstalk and mutual interference and, more importantly, 2) doesn't Verizon have exlcusive contracts for repeaters that carry cell phone reception inside transport hubs, such as the airport gates and subways? I think that's true on the Washington DC Metro, for example, and might skew Dave's results when he was in such places....anyone now for sure?

If you can't understand why a Mother or any family member would blog about the life after a tragic event, especially something that can spread awareness to others, then you have a cement heart and brain. Just hearing about the level of care that Noah needs in one 24 hour period, not to mention his new special diet, proves that his Mother spends plenty of time with her family. Maybe it is a therapy for her to vent about this, in hopes that it will prevent it from happening to another child. Do you really think she needs/wants people to feel sorry for her or their family? This isn't a pity party. Its not like their page is blanketed with advertisers and they are raking in the dough.

If just ONE care provider reads the harm shaking can cause to a child creates a lasting effect in a time of frustration or panic, then she has saved a life. From the number of followers they have, It seems like you may be one of the only people who don't "get it". Meanwhile, Trudy also has a website, I guess her husband should spend more time with his daughters, oh wait...he shipped them back to his country...

The trial and evidence presented did more justice than any newspaper article can, including testimony from the opposing opinions, one of which makes BIG bucks testifying at these trials all over the US. The jury was loaded with Northern Virginia professionals & parents. They ALL agreed she is guilty. Don't let the media put you your panties in a tizzy and get worked up over the spin of a journalist looking for ratings by leaving important details out of the story. NOT ONE JUROR BELIEVED SHE WAS INNOCENT.

As a parent in this situation: Who would YOU believe? A daycare provider or an investigator? A daycare provider or some of the TOP physicians in the world? Of COURSE Trudy didn't want the questioning recorded, DUH! Would ANY guilty party want their admission recorded? Is it too hard to believe the woman SNAPPED? How often do we see stories on Nancy Grace or the news where people SNAP and do crazy things to children? Sad but true. Why doesn't Trudy take a lie detector test?

The Whitmers never jumped to conclusions about what happened to Noah. They didn't immediately point fingers at Trudy. But from what the physicians told them combined with what the investigator revealed Trudy admitted, they moved forward in support of THE STATE prosecuting her. As any GOOD parent would, justice for their son. WHAT would you have done?

Yes, there may be stories and cases where people were wrongly accused. Yes, SBS is a very controversial subject. But also keep your mind open to the fact that YES, unfortunately people DO shake babies. Normal, happy, professionals, good people, SHAKE BABIES.

The anti-Mubarak force deserves the sympathy and support of all people in the world. Mubarak might not be very evil, and might have made contribution to Egyptian stability and the Middle East peace, but how presumptuous is he to think that he has the right to rule Egypt for more than three decades and to groom his son for the future? He and his family should leave Egypt, instead of dying on Egyptian soil. I admire the demonstrators’ courage and restraint, but hope that they would be more patient. With such a long and rich history, Egyptians should know that people cannot change history in a short period of time. I am not worried about the rise of Muslim Brothers or the threat to Israeli security, but I do think that Egyptians should not idealize a post-Mubarak Egypt.

So far as the US is concerned, I would play the devil’s advocate. Uncle Sam has already done more than enough. We have supported the dictator for so long, and called for restraint and stability not long ago. But the other day President Obama already sent a clear and forcible message that Mubarak should step down. The modern international system, for better or worse, is based on the principles of sovereignty and non-interference. Uncle Sam should not back Mubarak into the corner, so that he would have nothing to lose. We should negotiate a way out for him, letting him leave the country and live a decent life.

What is transpiring in Cairo reminds me of what happened in Beijing more than two decades ago. I hope that peace will prevail in Egypt, and wish the bloody clash on the Chinese New Year was only an unfortunate episode that would lead to peace and democracy in Egypt.

I'm sorry, but what have the Yankees, Dolphins and Lakers have to do with the EPL? Did I miss something here in a column about football (Yes, I know Americans insist on calling it soccer, but the world says FOOTBALL...)?

(Yes, Virginia, there is a world beyond the USA-one with many sports and many teams, most of which are multinational in structure and where politics are all but unknown and at the end of the matches the players are all friends.)

To the NYT, I ask why this obsession with the EPL? ManU isn't the only team in the UK any more than EPL is the only league there. As a matter of fact, ManU isn't even the only team in Manchester (that's England, not NH or IN) as someone obliquely mentioned in naming ManCity.

Personally I prefer the Rangers of the SPL---and love to watch Madjid Bougherra stop Wayne Ronney dead in his tracks. In fact it gives me great glee to know that only one defender amongst so many is consistently able to stop Rooney. Can't wait until the next meeting between the Rangers and ManU during another UEFA match.

One day, I hope, the NYT will get off its anglophile soapbox and share the other teams of not only the UK but of Europe, Africa and beyond with its readers. How about doing an article on the great rivalry between the Rangers and Celtic, preferably before the Rangers' Walter Smith retires?
